photo.description: The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". The large ceiling fresco. This fresco represents a brilliant highpoint of the joyous rococo style whereby the art of fresco painting and the art of stucco are combined with absolute perfection. The Resurrected Christ is the focal point of the painting. He is enthroned on the rainbow, a symbol of forgiveness and of the covenant with mankind reaching from the days of Noach up to the days when Christ will return to earth in all his glory. Jesus points to the cross as the sign of his love until death. He is accompanied by angels (among them Mary with halo and wings) and the twelve apostles to the left and right. The trompets of the Last Judgement, sounded by angels, announce that the trone of justice is prepared. Christ has not yet taken his place on his seat of justice, rather he rules from the rainbow and points to his wounded heart: love is the focal point of all existence and is the real seat of judgement, where God in his mercy and divine justice will pass judgement on each individual person as well as on all of humanity. more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Ze werd gebouwd in de late jaren 1740. In 1738 werden tranen gezien op een oud houten beeld van de Gegeselde Verlosser. Dit mirakel leidde tot een toevloed van bedevaarders. In 1740 werd een kleine kapel gebouwd om het beeld te huisvesten, maar al snel bleek dat het gebouw te klein was in verhouding met het aantal pelgrims dat het aantrok. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies
photo.tags: thewies bavaria germany pilgrimagechurch beieren pelgrims rococo duitsland
photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". The Organ: "A melody for the eye" The organ can be dated back to 1757. In 1959 the organ builder renovated the organ, returning it to the system of the baroque slider wind chest. Where possible the original pipes were built back into the organ. In 1929 the organ was remodeled in order to adapt it to a more modern style. more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Ze werd gebouwd in de late jaren 1740. In 1738 werden tranen gezien op een oud houten beeld van de Gegeselde Verlosser. Dit mirakel leidde tot een toevloed van bedevaarders. In 1740 werd een kleine kapel gebouwd om het beeld te huisvesten, maar al snel bleek dat het gebouw te klein was in verhouding met het aantal pelgrims dat het aantrok. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies

photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: The pilgrimage church of Wies (German: Wieskirche) is an oval rococo church, designed in the late 1740s by Dominikus Zimmermann, who spent the last eleven years of his life in a nearby dwelling. It is located in the foothills of the Alps, the Steingaden municipality of the Weilheim-Schongau district, Bavaria, Germany. In 1738 tears were seen on a dilapidated wooden figure of the Scourged Saviour. This miracle resulted in a pilgrimage rush to see the sculpture. In 1740 a small chapel was built to house the statue, but it was soon realized that the building would be too small for the number of pilgrims it attracted, and thus Steingaden Abbey decided to commission a separate shrine. Many people who have prayed in front of the statue of Jesus on the altar have claimed that people have been miraculously cured of their diseases, which has made this church even more of a pilgrimage site. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. Construction took place between 1745 and 1754, and the interior was decorated in stuccowork in the tradition of the Wessobrunner School. "Everything was done throughout the church to make the supernatural visible. Sculpture and murals combined to unleash the divine in visible form"[1]. The church, commonly regarded as Zimmermann's final masterpiece, was secularized in the beginning of the 19th century. Subsequently, protests of local farmers saved this jewel of rococo architecture and design from being sold and demolished. The Wieskirche was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1983 and underwent massive restoration in 1985-91.
photo.tags: churchwies rococoarchitecture bavarian germany wies deutschland wieskirche pilgrimage church wieskirchepilgrimagechurch
photo.title: Wies_3197

photo.description: The pilgrimage church of Wies (German: Wieskirche) is an oval rococo church, designed in the late 1740s by Dominikus Zimmermann, who spent the last eleven years of his life in a nearby dwelling. It is located in the foothills of the Alps, the Steingaden municipality of the Weilheim-Schongau district, Bavaria, Germany. In 1738 tears were seen on a dilapidated wooden figure of the Scourged Saviour. This miracle resulted in a pilgrimage rush to see the sculpture. In 1740 a small chapel was built to house the statue, but it was soon realized that the building would be too small for the number of pilgrims it attracted, and thus Steingaden Abbey decided to commission a separate shrine. Many people who have prayed in front of the statue of Jesus on the altar have claimed that people have been miraculously cured of their diseases, which has made this church even more of a pilgrimage site. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. Construction took place between 1745 and 1754, and the interior was decorated in stuccowork in the tradition of the Wessobrunner School. "Everything was done throughout the church to make the supernatural visible. Sculpture and murals combined to unleash the divine in visible form"[1]. The church, commonly regarded as Zimmermann's final masterpiece, was secularized in the beginning of the 19th century. Subsequently, protests of local farmers saved this jewel of rococo architecture and design from being sold and demolished. The Wieskirche was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1983 and underwent massive restoration in 1985-91.

photo.description: The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". The choir, the most sacred part of the church, is separated from the rest of the church by the communion rail which is decorated with rich inlaid woodwork. more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Ze werd gebouwd in de late jaren 1740. In 1738 werden tranen gezien op een oud houten beeld van de Gegeselde Verlosser. Dit mirakel leidde tot een toevloed van bedevaarders. In 1740 werd een kleine kapel gebouwd om het beeld te huisvesten, maar al snel bleek dat het gebouw te klein was in verhouding met het aantal pelgrims dat het aantrok. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies
photo.tags: thewies bavaria germany pilgrimagechurch beieren pelgrims rococo duitsland
photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". The Throne of Judgement in a state of Readiness. Again we are confronted with the colors red and blue. The deep red of the throne itself symbolizes the majesty of he who will be enthroned, he who gave his blood and life "to free us from our sins". Blue, the color of mercy, flows downward framing the throne with heavenly forgiveness and love. Angels at the throne hold open the Book of Life. more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Ze werd gebouwd in de late jaren 1740. In 1738 werden tranen gezien op een oud houten beeld van de Gegeselde Verlosser. Dit mirakel leidde tot een toevloed van bedevaarders. In 1740 werd een kleine kapel gebouwd om het beeld te huisvesten, maar al snel bleek dat het gebouw te klein was in verhouding met het aantal pelgrims dat het aantrok. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies
photo.tags: thewies bavaria germany pilgrimagechurch beieren pelgrims rococo duitsland
photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". The Pulpit. This pulpit abounds with life and spirit as stormy winds and cascades formed from stucco seem to make it come alive as a forum for the preaching of God's Word. more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. photo.description: The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". Saint Jerome, the leading translator of the Bible from Hebrew into Latin. Jerome (+420) the ascetic among the early Fathers, carries a skull as symbol of austerity. A highly educated scolar, he was, however, not a bishop. The baroque era bestowed the figure with a cardinal's hat, although during his lifetime such a hat did not exist. more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies

photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: The pilgrimage church of Wies (German: Wieskirche) is an oval rococo church, designed in the late 1740s by Dominikus Zimmermann, who spent the last eleven years of his life in a nearby dwelling. It is located in the foothills of the Alps, the Steingaden municipality of the Weilheim-Schongau district, Bavaria, Germany. In 1738 tears were seen on a dilapidated wooden figure of the Scourged Saviour. This miracle resulted in a pilgrimage rush to see the sculpture. In 1740 a small chapel was built to house the statue, but it was soon realized that the building would be too small for the number of pilgrims it attracted, and thus Steingaden Abbey decided to commission a separate shrine. Many people who have prayed in front of the statue of Jesus on the altar have claimed that people have been miraculously cured of their diseases, which has made this church even more of a pilgrimage site. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. Construction took place between 1745 and 1754, and the interior was decorated in stuccowork in the tradition of the Wessobrunner School. "Everything was done throughout the church to make the supernatural visible. Sculpture and murals combined to unleash the divine in visible form"[1]. The church, commonly regarded as Zimmermann's final masterpiece, was secularized in the beginning of the 19th century. Subsequently, protests of local farmers saved this jewel of rococo architecture and design from being sold and demolished. The Wieskirche was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1983 and underwent massive restoration in 1985-91.
photo.tags: churchwies bavarian germany wies deutschland themostbeautifulplacesineurope wieskirche pilgrimage church wieskirchepilgrimagechurch
photo.title: Wies_3211

photo.description: The pilgrimage church of Wies (German: Wieskirche) is an oval rococo church, designed in the late 1740s by Dominikus Zimmermann, who spent the last eleven years of his life in a nearby dwelling. It is located in the foothills of the Alps, the Steingaden municipality of the Weilheim-Schongau district, Bavaria, Germany.. In 1738 tears were seen on a dilapidated wooden figure of the Scourged Saviour. This miracle resulted in a pilgrimage rush to see the sculpture. In 1740 a small chapel was built to house the statue, but it was soon realized that the building would be too small for the number of pilgrims it attracted, and thus Steingaden Abbey decided to commission a separate shrine. Many people who have prayed in front of the statue of Jesus on the altar have claimed that people have been miraculously cured of their diseases, which has made this church even more of a pilgrimage site. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. Construction took place between 1745 and 1754, and the interior was decorated in stuccowork in the tradition of the Wessobrunner School. "Everything was done throughout the church to make the supernatural visible. Sculpture and murals combined to unleash the divine in visible form"[1]. The church, commonly regarded as Zimmermann's final masterpiece, was secularized in the beginning of the 19th century. Subsequently, protests of local farmers saved this jewel of rococo architecture and design from being sold and demolished. The Wieskirche was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1983 and underwent massive restoration in 1985-91.

photo.description: Gate to Eternity. Opposite the Throne of judgement we find the Gate to Eternity. It is still closed but it announces the days to come: "Tempus non erit amplis" - "From now on time will be no more" (Rv 10,6). The figure Cronos, symbolizing time, lies, a broken figure, on the ground. His instrument for measuring time, the hour glass, has slipped out of his hand as has the scythe with witch he will cut the treath of life and reap the last harvest. On the left side an angel appears carrying the "Book of Revelation" (Rv 10). The angel swears by Him who lives for ever and ever, the Creator of Heaven and Earth, that: "From now on time will be no more". Eternity begins, symbolized by a snake forming a ring without beginning or ending. The door shows the cross which is a symbol of hope and the key to heaven. The gate to Eternity has not opened for us yet. There is still time for each of us, in our own small ways, to be a part of God's order to shape the events of the world. The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Ze werd gebouwd in de late jaren 1740. In 1738 werden tranen gezien op een oud houten beeld van de Gegeselde Verlosser. Dit mirakel leidde tot een toevloed van bedevaarders. In 1740 werd een kleine kapel gebouwd om het beeld te huisvesten, maar al snel bleek dat het gebouw te klein was in verhouding met het aantal pelgrims dat het aantrok. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies
photo.tags: thewies bavaria germany pilgrimagechurch beieren pelgrims rococo duitsland cronos god
photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: Gate to Eternity. Opposite the Throne of judgement we find the Gate to Eternity. It is still closed but it announces the days to come: "Tempus non erit amplis" - "From now on time will be no more" (Rv 10,6). The figure Cronos, symbolizing time, lies, a broken figure, on the ground. His instrument for measuring time, the hour glass, has slipped out of his hand as has the scythe with witch he will cut the treath of life and reap the last harvest. On the left side an angel appears carrying the "Book of Revelation" (Rv 10). The angel swears by Him who lives for ever and ever, the Creator of Heaven and Earth, that: "From now on time will be no more". Eternity begins, symbolized by a snake forming a ring without beginning or ending. The door shows the cross which is a symbol of hope and the key to heaven. The gate to Eternity has not opened for us yet. There is still time for each of us, in our own small ways, to be a part of God's order to shape the events of the world. The Wies. Pilgrimage Church of the "Scourged Saviour". more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wies_Church De Bedevaartskerk van Wies (Duits: Wieskirche) is een ovale rococokerk, gelegen in de plaats Wies, gemeente Steingaden (Beieren) aan de voet van de Alpen in Duitsland. Ze werd gebouwd in de late jaren 1740. In 1738 werden tranen gezien op een oud houten beeld van de Gegeselde Verlosser. Dit mirakel leidde tot een toevloed van bedevaarders. In 1740 werd een kleine kapel gebouwd om het beeld te huisvesten, maar al snel bleek dat het gebouw te klein was in verhouding met het aantal pelgrims dat het aantrok. Daarop besliste de abdij van Steingaden om er een afzonderlijke kerk aan te wijden. uit: nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedevaartskerk_van_Wies

photo.title: The Wies - Bavaria - Germany

photo.description: The pilgrimage church of Wies (German: Wieskirche) is an oval rococo church, designed in the late 1740s by Dominikus Zimmermann, who spent the last eleven years of his life in a nearby dwelling. It is located in the foothills of the Alps, the Steingaden municipality of the Weilheim-Schongau district, Bavaria, Germany. In 1738 tears were seen on a dilapidated wooden figure of the Scourged Saviour. This miracle resulted in a pilgrimage rush to see the sculpture. In 1740 a small chapel was built to house the statue, but it was soon realized that the building would be too small for the number of pilgrims it attracted, and thus Steingaden Abbey decided to commission a separate shrine. Many people who have prayed in front of the statue of Jesus on the altar have claimed that people have been miraculously cured of their diseases, which has made this church even more of a pilgrimage site. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. In contrast to the riotous interior, the exterior of the church does not display the ostentatious theatricality and striving for effect typical of that time. Construction took place between 1745 and 1754, and the interior was decorated in stuccowork in the tradition of the Wessobrunner School. "Everything was done throughout the church to make the supernatural visible. Sculpture and murals combined to unleash the divine in visible form"[1]. The church, commonly regarded as Zimmermann's final masterpiece, was secularized in the beginning of the 19th century. Subsequently, protests of local farmers saved this jewel of rococo architecture and design from being sold and demolished. The Wieskirche was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1983 and underwent massive restoration in 1985-91.

photo.description: The Pilgrimage Church of Wies (Wieskirche) is an oval rococo church designed in the late 1740s. Located in the foothills of the Alps, in the municipality of Steingaden in the Weilheim-Schongau district, Bavaria, Germany, the Wieskirche was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1983 and underwent extensive restoration between 1985 and 1991. In 1738, tears were seen on a dilapidated wooden figure of the Scourged Saviour and pilgrimage rush started to the sculpture. Many who have prayed in front of the statue of Jesus on the altar, have claimed that have been miraculously cured of their diseases, and sent gifts to the church exposed in two hallways on both sides of the altar.
